MODERATOR: Good morning, folks, and welcome
to the Foreign Press Center. We’re pleased

3.57.text:
to have all of you here today for this briefing
on climate change in the Arctic. We are joined

8.29.text:
today by two experts, colleagues from the
National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration,

15.39.text:
Dr. Jeff Key and Dr. Ed Farley. They’ll
be talking first about their research related

21.36.text:
to Arctic climate change, and then after that
we’ll go on to your questions.

24.97.text:
Our first speaker this morning will be Dr.
Jeff Key. He’s the branch chief for advanced

30.01.text:
satellite products branch at the Center for
Satellite Applications and Research, which

34.46.text:
is part of NOAA’s Satellite and Information
Service. And his topic is observing Arctic

45.20.text:
DR KEY: Thank you, Mike. I am happy to be
here and have this opportunity to speak briefly

52.96.text:
about how we use satellites to observe the
Arctic, and perhaps more importantly, what

58.65.text:
we’ve learned about Arctic climate change
looking down from space. As you can see here,

64.36.text:
one of the themes is that what happens in
the Arctic doesn’t stay in the Arctic, and

68.74.text:
I’ll address that theme throughout the rest
of this short presentation.

75.85.text:
So first, I want to spend a little bit of
time showing you what the Arctic looks like

80.44.text:
from space in various ways. And this is an
illustration that doesn’t really show us

85.63.text:
what the Arctic looks like from space, because
it’s a composite of different types of satellite

90.25.text:
data made specifically to eliminate the atmosphere
and let you see the surface. So you don’t

95.93.text:
see clouds here, which of course you would
see from space. But what I like about this

100.13.text:
illustration is that it makes the point very
clearly that the Arctic is an ocean surrounded

105.88.text:
by land, which is very much in contrast to
the Antarctic at the opposite end of the earth,

111.89.text:
so to speak, which is a continent, which is
land surrounded by ocean. That has significant

118.89.text:
implications for the reaction of the two polar
regions to changes in global climate. So here,

125.91.text: we’re only talking about the Arctic.

129.22.text:
This is perhaps more a better view of what
the Arctic would look like from space, without

135.32.text:
all the labels, of course. But here we see
clouds and sea ice and the Greenland ice sheet

140.62.text:
down there in the lower left. We see some
snow-covered land and snow-free land, and

146.19.text:
this gives a good flavor of the complexity
of the Arctic climate system.

152.30.text:
From space, we can look at very high resolution
to see the very fine details of the surface

157.21.text:
if we want to. Here, you can see sea ice at
a pretty high resolution, about 250 meters.

163.58.text:
We have higher resolution instruments than
that. But here we see ice flows. We even see

168.48.text:
the little ridges on the ice flows and we
see ice with different thicknesses between

175.93.text:
Zooming back out a little bit and moving over
land, we use satellites to monitor glaciers,

181.51.text:
alpine glaciers. We can measure their area,
their movement, and their change over time,

187.39.text: and of course, snow cover as well.

189.75.text:
And then zooming way out, we can combine many
different satellites from many different countries

195.91.text:
– some of your countries and U.S. satellites
as well – put them together to get a very

201.19.text:
nice picture of atmospheric circulation around
the north polar region.

208.65.text:
What you’re used to seeing from satellite,
particularly on the weather reports on television,

213.81.text:
is visible data, something that you would
see with your own eye. Sometimes, we see infrared

219.04.text:
data as well. The problem is in the polar
regions, with all the snow and ice, it’s

224.34.text:
difficult to determine the properties of those
physical parts of the system and distinguish

230.29.text:
them from clouds, for example, in just the
visible part of the spectrum.

234.62.text:
So we need to look at the Arctic and the Antarctic
with what I’m calling here alien vision,

240.95.text:
meaning something beyond the visible portion
of the spectrum – near-infrared, infrared,

246.78.text:
microwave. And in microwave, we have passive
microwave, which is just what our bodies are

253.23.text:
emitting at a very long wavelength, and active
microwave, which we know better as radar,

258.40.text:
where we send a signal down from the satellite
and measure its return. And with all of these

263.79.text:
different types of data, we can determine
snow properties, ice thickness, cloud particle

269.59.text:
sizes – not every single little particle,
but overall – and so forth.

275.93.text:
We also need gravity. Gravity is very important
for Arctic climate change and also for Antarctic

281.15.text:
climate change because it tells us the difference
– how the ice sheets in particular change

286.72.text:
over time, but it can also tell us how snow
cover is changing.

292.50.text:
So the first point I want to make is that
a comprehensive space-based observing system

297.87.text:
needs a multitude of satellite censors, and
no single space agency – not NASA, not NOAA,

305.11.text:
not JAXA, not EUMETSAT – provides all of
the sensors that we really need to robustly

311.05.text:
observe the Arctic. So we need international
partnerships, and I think NOAA has been very

316.12.text:
good about forging those partnerships and
needs to continue doing that in the future.

321.54.text:
From satellites, we measure very basic information.
It’s upwelling radiation – not dangerous

329.19.text:
radiation, but visible infrared, microwave
radiation. We need to turn that into something

334.72.text:
that we can use to study changes in the Arctic
climate system, like snow cover and ice cover,

340.56.text:
as we see here in this animation. And we retrieve,
we estimate, many different properties of

346.66.text:
the physical system, as I have listed here,
including cloud properties, ice thickness

351.87.text:
– sea ice thickness in particular – atmospheric
chemistry, winds, for example here. Many different

359.19.text: things that I don’t have time to show.

362.49.text:
So the second point I want to make is that
we estimate many properties of the physical

366.94.text:
climate system from space, and all of these
have operational applications. We use sea

373.02.text:
ice for shipping and for our oil and gas exploration.
We use information about the atmosphere as

379.27.text:
well as snow cover in numerical weather prediction
all over the world. But all these properties

386.21.text:
also have climatological implications as well,
and we use them in climate studies. Probably

392.43.text:
the most popular trend in the Arctic that
people have seen over the years is how sea

397.83.text:
ice cover has changed. We all know that it’s
been decreasing. That’s not new news. That’s,

403.17.text:
in some sense, old news. What’s perhaps
newest about it is that we’ve had record

408.51.text:
minima in the ice cover in 2007 and again
in 2012, and then a fairly significant rebound

416.08.text: in 2013 and 2014. But the trend is still downward.

421.15.text:
What’s newer and what I’m not showing
here is that we have new products from space

426.22.text:
that estimate sea ice thickness, and we’ve
applied one of our own products to 30 years

431.44.text:
of data; and we now know that not only has
the Arctic ice pack been thinning, but we

437.18.text:
know exactly where and in what – to what
magnitude and what degree over the last 30-plus

444.29.text:
years. So that’s new information we’re
very excited about, and we’ll continue to

452.70.text:
From space we also observe how the atmosphere
is changing – winds, chemistry, temperature,

457.86.text:
humidity. Here’s an example of how winds
have changed. We know that the polar jet stream

463.95.text:
has shifted. It’s strengthened somewhat
over Eurasia but weakened over Canada. What’s

469.58.text:
important about that is that this affects
mid-latitude climate. As the jet stream weakens,

475.77.text:
it tends to meander more, and we get more
extreme weather in the mid latitudes. So here’s

481.43.text:
another example of what happens in the Arctic
isn’t staying in the Arctic.

488.67.text:
Vegetation has changed. Plant growth has increased
up to 10 percent in some areas. It’s not

493.59.text:
just getting greener; it’s changing in character.
So if we replace tundra vegetation with shrubs,

500.42.text:
for example, that changes how much sunlight
is reflected, and there can be a feedback

505.52.text:
effect where actually a change in vegetation
can lead to even greater warming, which leads

510.78.text: to a greater change in vegetation and so forth.

515.76.text:
The last point I want to make is not about
changes in individual properties of the climate

521.48.text:
system, but from space, by combining many
different types of satellites, we can also

527.25.text:
look at how these – the different components
of the climate system interact. And what we’ve

532.48.text:
learned very recently, and haven’t even
published this yet, is that changes in wintertime

537.28.text:
cloud cover can affect summertime sea ice.
And that’s hard to grasp because we’re

542.79.text:
talking about a difference in time of seven
to nine months. Look at the cloud cover outside

548.58.text:
now; can you predict what’s going to change,
how that – what effect that’s going to

553.02.text:
have nine months from now? Very difficult,
but we found a very strong relationship about

558.60.text:
the – how clouds in the winter affect summertime
sea ice. This will help us improve short-term

566.06.text:
sea ice forecasts. So the fourth point I want
to make is that satellites can be used not

571.18.text:
just to study individual properties of the
climate system, but also the feedbacks and

578.19.text:
So what does all this matter? Well, changes
in sea ice impact shipping, fisheries – as

583.09.text:
we’ll hear from Ed Farley in the next presentation
– coastal erosion, wildlife, and weather,

590.56.text:
as I’ve just pointed out. Changes in snow
cover impact water supply, which is very important

596.55.text:
to many especially arid countries. Also weather,
agriculture; a warming Arctic means a thawing

604.44.text:
permafrost, which impacts infrastructure.
And of course, the big one is that melting

611.07.text:
ice sheets cause an increase in sea level
or a sea level rise, and that’ll impact

616.26.text: any coastal city anywhere in the world.

619.74.text:
So again, Arctic processes affect global climate.
What happens in the Arctic doesn’t stay

624.66.text:
in the Arctic. Satellites have been critical
– essential – to discovering, monitoring,

631.42.text:
and quantifying changes in sea ice thickness
– that’s new – plant growth, changes

638.41.text:
in circulation, melting of ice sheets. And
we’re also using satellites to look at relationships

645.15.text:
between parts of the climate system – (cell
phone beeps) – sorry, that was mine. (Laughter.)

651.32.text:
And a new discovery, I think, is that the
clouds have actually been reducing the magnitude

658.54.text:
– or reducing, holding in check the magnitude
of Arctic warming. The way clouds have been

663.04.text:
changing over time has actually acted to reduce
the amount of warming that’s occurring in

670.61.text:
the Arctic, and that’s a very important
point from a climatological perspective.

674.35.text:
Once again, we need lots of different satellite
sensors. No single U.S. agency or agency in

681.65.text:
any other country has all the sensors we need.
We need to continue to promote, facilitate

689.72.text:
Now, having said all that about satellites
and how great they are for observing the Arctic,

695.18.text:
we can’t see everything from space. And
in fact, we’ll hear about one aspect of

699.49.text:
the Arctic climate change that we can’t
hear in a minute from Ed on fisheries. Thank

The focus of this talk is going to be sea

to focus on some of what changes occur between

is a beneficial fish food for fish, and some
of the small zooplankton, which I’ll show

763.25.text:
So the focus of the talk here is going to
be in the Arctic, which is up in the north

in the Chukchi Sea. And again, Jeff just highlighted

I’ll go into that in a few more minutes
in a little more detail. And I’m going to

start with the subarctic, which is in the
southeastern Bering Sea. It’s that continental

780.61.text:
shelf down in the bottom part of the picture
there. And the issue here is sea ice extent

788.47.text:
and duration during spring and how that might
impact the availability of large versus small

794.71.text:
zooplankton for fish. And one of the things
I want to mention, that if you’re a fish

or a marine mammal in this region, you’re

803.59.text:
before winter so you have a better chance
to survive during winter. So that’s why

809.42.text:
So I’m going to begin here. Our research
has indicated that when we have early ice

817.00.text:
retreat, we get a plant bloom that’s feeding
the zooplankton, mostly small zooplankton,

824.24.text:
and that these small zooplankton have less
fat. So early ice retreat is typically related

830.18.text:
to warming temperatures. And when we have
a late ice retreat, usually related to colder

836.71.text:
winters and colder springs, we get an earlier
plant bloom that feeds a different component

843.12.text:
of our zooplankton. It’s the large zooplankton,
and we’ve now found out that those zooplankton

852.50.text:
So if we look into an example, which I’ll
pull into fisheries here in just a moment,

857.16.text:
we have a period of time – most recently
2002 through 2005 – where there was an early

862.60.text:
ice retreat. And that area that you see down
in the subarctic, which is right down in this

870.00.text:
region right here – you see from satellite
image there’s very little ice down there.

875.05.text:
That’s in May 2002 compared with May 2012,
which was similar to a period of late ice

881.55.text:
retreat from 2007 through 2012. And here you
can see that in that time period, there’s

887.67.text:
ice extending all the way down into that subarctic

893.04.text:
So one of the major fisheries in the subarctic
is our walleye pollock fishery. Walleye pollock

899.81.text:
have a commercial value of around half a billion
dollars annually from 2012 McDowell Group.

907.09.text:
They’re also utilized for fake crab – many
of you may have had that – and premium fish

914.84.text:
sticks, such as the example I show here. And
in that time period that I am showing here

920.31.text:
from 1994 through 2014, we see that there
was a downward trend in the biomass or thousands

928.85.text:
of tons of pollock that were available in
the Bering Sea. That was followed again by

936.59.text:
an increase, but if we focus on this downward
trend, that tended to occur during that early

941.99.text:
ice retreat period. That drop amounted to
a 40 percent drop in available pollock catch,

947.74.text:
so that was a big issue. No one really understood
why the pollock biomass was declining, but

954.70.text:
it was impacting the fishery. It was followed
then by a recovery, fortunately, and that

961.00.text:
occurred during what we saw as this late ice
retreat period.

965.16.text:
So, as I mentioned before, when we get early
ice retreat, we get these smaller zooplankton

972.24.text:
with less fat. When we get the late ice retreat,
we get larger zooplankton with more fat, and

978.26.text:
this is just an example of some of the zooplankton
types. The top four are small zooplankton;

983.89.text:
the bottom two are large zooplankton, and
you can see just in the figures here there’s

988.28.text:
about two times more fat in the large zooplankton
than in the small zooplankton. Not only that;

994.17.text:
we see there is even a difference in the amount
of fat with all the zooplankton types between

1000.10.text:
the late ice retreat and early ice retreat.
But the take-home message here is if you’re

1004.61.text:
a fish, you want to eat the large zooplankton,
you get a better food packet.

1008.91.text:
And if we look at what our fish were eating
– these are the young fish that we’re

1013.63.text:
studying – we can see that overall in the
early ice retreat period they were feeding

1017.77.text:
more on small zooplankton because they were
more populous in the environment that they

1022.64.text:
were swimming in. Then we move into the late
ice retreat; they were feeding more on large

1027.49.text:
zooplankton because those large zooplankton
were more abundant in that period. And if

1033.64.text:
we – we all know that you are what you eat,
and if you look at the condition of these

1040.42.text:
young pollock in that early ice retreat period,
they – this is a measure of fat – their

1046.80.text:
fat content was much less than it was in that
late ice retreat period. So again, they were

1053.83.text:
feeding on, in this late ice retreat period,
better food, giving them more fat, more storage

1064.10.text:
And just to show you, we’ve related that
amount of fat to the survival of these pollock,

1068.42.text:
and we can see there’s a nice linear relationship
there just indicating the more fat that they

1072.78.text:
have prior to winter, the better they’re
going to survive. So the mechanism then is

1077.48.text:
really how ice is impacting the type of fish
food, either low-fat fish food or high-fat

1085.36.text:
fish food, and how that fat reserve impacts
winter survival, and that drives mortality

1092.45.text:
in this – in that low-fat reserve period,
early ice retreat period versus a high-fat

1098.23.text: reserve period, which is the late ice retreat.

1102.74.text:
So if we move up into the Chukchi Sea now
into the Arctic, the issue there is declining

1107.49.text:
sea ice extent, as Jeff had mentioned. And
this is during September, so if you remove

1112.56.text:
the ice, ice is a reflective surface and the
sunlight then hits that reflective surface;

1117.95.text:
most of that energy is bounced back up into
the atmosphere. But if you have less ice there,

1122.79.text:
you’ve got water, which is darker, and so
more of the sunlight is hitting that water

1127.18.text:
and that energy is impacting the sea surface,
the sea temperatures, by increasing sea temperature.

1133.69.text:
So an increase in temperature is – may – we’re
going to find out what might happen with some

1137.87.text: of the more important species here.

1141.84.text:
And from here we’re moving up one level
to a fish called the arctic cod. It’s an

1146.72.text:
extremely important fish in this food web.
I don’t have the plants here, but you have

1152.01.text:
plants that go to the zooplankton, which feed
arctic cod, which again feed these ice seals,

1157.87.text:
which are extremely important to polar bears.
And again, in this region, the more fat you

1162.43.text:
store in the summertime gives you better survival
for winter.

1166.63.text:
There’s also another fish in this region
called the saffron cod, so I’m going to

1170.56.text:
give you just an example of some of the research
we’ve done to show differences in these

1174.38.text:
arctic cod, which are real important, versus
saffron cod. A survey we conducted the past

1181.68.text:
couple of years shows that over at the far
left-hand corner of the screen that the arctic

cod are extremely abundant in this region
of the Chukchi Sea and the Arctic, and more

1194.15.text:
so than the saffron cod. The main issue here

1198.83.text:
to seas temperature and that the arctic cod

1205.43.text:
between about 3 and 6 degrees Celsius, whereas

water in the near shore in about 9 to 12 degrees

1218.80.text:
So what’s the difference between these two

1223.16.text:
in this region that are available for ice
seals and other marine mammals? Well, the

1229.74.text:
difference is that these arctic cod have about

cod. So if you’re an ice seal, you’re

cod to get the same amount of fat as you get

1244.80.text:
We’ve also done some experiments on growth

1251.35.text:
species. And the one highlight here that I
want you to see is the temperatures on the

1256.17.text:
bottom there. It’s in Celsius again. But
arctic cod, that curve is in blue. Their growth

rate is a maximum at about 7 degrees Celsius,
as opposed to saffron cod where the maximum

growth rate is about 15 degrees C. So arctic

1275.61.text:
if they get above 7 degrees Celsius, their
growth rate declines and they tend to, above

1280.70.text:
10, begin to die. So warming water is not
good for arctic cod, whereas it’s very good

1290.79.text:
And one of the models – some of the models

1296.78.text:
sea temperatures into the end of the century,
suggests that that area that we see, those

1302.99.text:
arctic cod distributed in our most recent
surveys, is going to warm up to about 10 to

13 degrees Celsius, and that is a potential

going to be moving out – either move out

some of the information and some of the research

the implications of a potential warming in

So the conclusion is, as we continue to warm

fisheries. And then in the Arctic, we’re

up there may not be very good for arctic cod,
